items.def: Outermost layer of physical security including fencing, gates, lighting, and landscaping to deter and detect unauthorized access.
Small room with two interlocking doors ensuring only one person passes at a time, preventing tailgating and piggybacking.
Short vertical posts preventing vehicle access to sensitive areas while allowing pedestrian traffic.
Identification cards with magnetic stripes, proximity readers, or smart chips granting authorized physical access.
Physical access control using unique biological characteristics (fingerprint, iris, facial recognition, hand geometry).
Personnel monitoring facilities, verifying identities, responding to incidents, and providing human judgment in security decisions.
Traditional physical security mechanisms. Include mechanical locks, electronic locks, cipher locks, and key management systems.
Cameras monitoring and recording activities in and around facilities. Provides deterrence, detection, and forensic evidence.
Process verifying user identity before granting system access using credentials like passwords, tokens, or biometrics.
Determining what resources and actions authenticated users are permitted to access based on permissions and privileges.
Recording user activities, access attempts, and system events for security monitoring, compliance, and forensic investigation.
Lists defining which users or systems have permission to access specific resources and what operations they can perform.
Process of creating, modifying, and deleting user accounts and permissions as employees join, change roles, or leave.
Removing user access rights when employees leave or no longer need access. Critical for preventing unauthorized access.
Owner of resource controls access permissions. Flexible but less secure. Users can grant access to others (Windows NTFS).
System enforces access based on security labels and clearances. Rigid but highly secure. Used in military and classified environments.
Access based on user roles within organization. Scalable and manageable. Permissions assigned to roles, users assigned to roles.
Access determined by administrator-defined rules (time of day, location, device type). Applied globally across systems.
Dynamic access decisions based on user attributes, resource attributes, and environmental conditions. Highly granular and flexible.
Knowledge-based authentication: passwords, PINs, passphrases, security questions. Most common but vulnerable to social engineering.
Possession-based authentication: smart cards, hardware tokens, mobile devices, key fobs. Physical object required for access.
Biometric authentication: fingerprints, facial recognition, iris scans, voice recognition, palm prints. Based on physical characteristics.
Behavioral biometrics: typing patterns, signature dynamics, gait analysis. Based on unique behavioral characteristics.
Location-based authentication: GPS coordinates, IP address geolocation, network location. Context-aware access control.
Combining two or more different authentication factors. Significantly increases security by requiring multiple verification methods.
Requirements for minimum length, character types (uppercase, lowercase, numbers, symbols) making passwords harder to crack.
Policy requiring users to change passwords periodically. Modern guidance questions frequent changes due to user behavior.
System tracking previous passwords preventing users from reusing recent passwords when required to change.
Automatic account disabling after specified number of failed login attempts. Prevents brute force attacks but enables DoS.
Software securely storing and generating complex unique passwords. Users remember one strong master password.
One-way cryptographic transformation storing passwords securely. Systems compare hashes, never storing plaintext passwords.
Random data added to passwords before hashing. Prevents rainbow table attacks and ensures identical passwords have different hashes.
Authentication once to access multiple applications within same organization. Improves user experience and reduces password fatigue.
Trusted relationship between organizations allowing users to access resources across domains using single set of credentials.
XML-based standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data between identity provider and service provider.
Open standard for token-based authorization allowing third-party applications limited access to user resources without exposing passwords.
Authentication layer built on OAuth 2.0 enabling client applications to verify user identity based on authentication by authorization server.
System that creates, maintains, and manages identity information while providing authentication services to applications.
Account with elevated permissions exceeding normal users. Includes administrator, root, service accounts. High-value targets.
Granting minimum access rights necessary to perform job functions. Reduces risk from compromised accounts or insider threats.
Solutions managing, monitoring, and securing privileged accounts. Includes password vaulting, session monitoring, just-in-time access.
Granting elevated privileges only when needed for specific period. Access automatically expires, reducing standing privileges.
Recording and analyzing activities performed using privileged accounts for security monitoring and compliance.
Non-human account used by applications and services. Often have broad permissions and require special management.
Dividing critical tasks among multiple people preventing any single person from compromising security or committing fraud.
Granting access only to information required for specific job responsibilities, regardless of security clearance level.
Periodically moving employees between roles. Detects fraud, reduces insider threat risk, ensures knowledge distribution.
Requiring employees to take consecutive time off. Helps detect fraudulent activities that require continuous presence.
Limiting system access to specific hours matching work schedules. Detects unauthorized access during off-hours.
Periodic examination of user permissions ensuring access remains appropriate. Remove unnecessary privileges and orphaned accounts.
Formal processes for granting access when employees join and promptly removing access when they leave or change roles.
Centralized systems storing and managing user accounts and permissions. Examples: Active Directory, LDAP, Azure AD.
Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service. Protocol providing centralized authentication, authorization, and accounting for network access.
Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System Plus. Cisco protocol separating authentication, authorization, and accounting. More granular than RADIUS.
Network authentication protocol using tickets and symmetric key cryptography. Prevents password transmission over networks.
Using digital certificates and PKI to verify identity. More secure than passwords, used for VPNs, wireless networks, websites.
Physical card with embedded chip storing digital certificates and cryptographic keys for strong authentication.
Records of system activities including logins, file access, configuration changes. Essential for security monitoring and compliance.
Tracking and recording user actions within systems for security analysis, insider threat detection, and compliance.
Recording unsuccessful authentication attempts. Multiple failures may indicate brute force attacks or credential guessing.
Identifying unusual access patterns or behaviors deviating from normal baselines. May indicate compromised accounts.
Policy defining how long audit logs are stored. Balances forensic needs, compliance requirements, and storage costs.
Platform aggregating and analyzing log data from multiple sources for real-time security monitoring and incident detection.
Threshold for acceptable number of violations before triggering alerts. Reduces false positives from normal errors.

items.description: Protect physical assets and facilities. Guards, locks, badges, cameras, fences. Tangible security measures.
Protect digital resources and data. Passwords, permissions, encryption, firewalls. Technology-based security measures.
Both essential for defense in depth. Physical security protects systems; logical security protects data. Complement each other.
Owner controls access. Flexible but risky. Users can share access. Common in commercial systems (Windows, Linux).
System enforces access via labels. Rigid but secure. Users cannot override. Used in classified environments.
Access based on job roles. Scalable for enterprises. Permissions assigned to roles, users assigned to roles.
Verifying identity (Who are you?). Proving you are who you claim to be. First step in access control.
Granting permissions (What can you do?). Determining access rights after authentication. Second step in access control.
Always authenticate first, then authorize. Cannot authorize without knowing identity. Both required for secure access.
Claiming identity (username, employee ID). Making an assertion about who you are. No proof required yet.
Proving identity (password, biometric). Providing evidence supporting your identity claim. Verification step.
Granting access based on identity. Determining permissions and privileges. Access decision step.
One authentication for multiple applications within organization. Internal systems. Centralized authentication.
Authentication across organizational boundaries. Trust relationships between organizations. Cross-domain access (SAML, OAuth).
Combines authentication and authorization. UDP transport. Encrypts only password. Open standard. Network access focus.
Separates AAA functions. TCP transport. Encrypts entire payload. Cisco proprietary. Device administration focus. More granular.

comparisons.title: Something You Know vs Have vs Are

items.description: Knowledge factor: passwords, PINs, answers. Vulnerable to sharing, guessing, social engineering. Easiest to implement.
Possession factor: tokens, cards, phones. Can be lost or stolen. Physical object required.
Inherence factor: biometrics (fingerprint, face, iris). Cannot be shared or lost. Privacy concerns. Most secure.
Single authority managing access (Active Directory, LDAP). Consistent policies. Easier management. Single point of failure.
Multiple authorities managing their own resources. Local control. Harder to maintain consistency. No single point of failure.
Default: everything not explicitly permitted is denied. Secure by default. Common in firewalls and access controls.
Specifically stated denial of access. Overrides permit rules. Used for exceptions to general permit rules.

comparisons.title: Access Control List vs Capability List

items.description: Resource-centric. Lists users/groups with access to specific resource. Attached to objects. Easy to see who accesses resource.
User-centric. Lists resources accessible by specific user. Attached to subjects. Easy to see what user can access.
Temporary automatic suspension after failed login attempts. Prevents brute force. Auto-unlocks after time or admin action.
Manual permanent or long-term deactivation. For terminated employees, unused accounts, policy violations. Requires admin to re-enable.
Authorization framework. Allows limited access to resources without sharing passwords. Access tokens. Delegation protocol.
Authentication layer built on OAuth 2.0. Verifies user identity. ID tokens in addition to access tokens. Adds authentication to OAuth.
